issues.text: Whether the appellants were denied a fair hearing because Mr. Justice Sharma did not allow them a chance to reply to the arguments on behalf of the State?

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before us by Mr. Tewatia that Mr. Justice Sharma who delivered the judgment impugned before us did not allow the appellants a chance to reply to the arguments on behalf of the State and thus denied them a fair hearing. This fact was mentioned

issues.text: Whether the prior acquittal in the second case operates as a bar to the conviction in the present case under the principle of res judicata or autrefois acquit as per s. 403 CrPC?

anchor.surface_text: The next contention of the appellants is that the prior acquittal in the second case operates as a bar to the conviction in the present case and the High Court ought to have given the appellants the benefit of the prior ac- quittal. Reliance in this connection is placed upon a de- cision

issues.text: Whether the earlier judgment in the second case is admissible and relevant for the purpose of appreciating the evidence or destroying the prosecution case in the present appeal?
Whether this Court should review for the third time the evidence accepted by the High Court and Sessions Court?

arguments.claim: Mr. Justice Sharma did not allow the appellants a chance to reply to the arguments on behalf of the State and thus denied them a fair hearing

anchor.surface_text: It was contended before us by Mr. Tewatia that Mr. Justice Sharma who delivered the judgment impugned before us did number allow the appellants a chance to reply to the arguments on behalf of the State and thus denied them a fair hearing. This fact was mentioned

court_response_anchor.surface_text: upon a de- cision of the Privy Council in a case from Malaya State reported in Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor Federation of Malaya 1  and particular

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellants did not bring the matter to the notice of the judge immediately for rectification and did not press it before him despite mentioning in petition for certificate

arguments.claim: The prior acquittal in the second case operates as a bar to the conviction in the present case under res judicata or autrefois acquit and High Court ought to have given benefit of prior acquittal

anchor.surface_text: The next contention of the appellants is that the prior acquittal in the second case operates as a bar to the conviction in the present case and the High Court ought to have given the appellants the benefit of the prior ac- quittal. Reliance in this connection is placed upon a de- cision

arguments.court_reasoning: Precedents like Sambasivam and Pritam Singh distinguished as they involved indivisible confession or same evidence affecting admissibility; here offences distinct in time and place, s.403 CrPC not applicable as not same offence or under s.236/237 doubtful cases; separate trials proper

arguments.claim: The earlier judgment in the second case involved almost the same evidence and its reasoning destroys the prosecution case in the present appeal
arguments.court_reasoning: Earlier judgment admissible under ss.40-43 Evidence Act only to show parties and decision, not for appreciation of evidence; evidence separately recorded and considered; different number of eyewitnesses

arguments.claim: This Court does not review for the third time evidence accepted by High Court and trial court absent special circumstances

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Tewatia attempted to argue on the facts of this case but we did number permit him to do so because this Court, in the absence of special circumstances, does number review for the third time, evidence, which has been accepted in the High Court and the Court below.

arguments.claim: The two offences were distinct transactions separated by time and place requiring separate charges and trials; Sessions Judge rightly separated them

anchor.surface_text: Neither of these provisions is applicable to the present facts because the two offences were distinct and spaced slightly by time and place. The trials were separate as the two incidents were viewed as distinct transactions.

holdings.text: The contention that the appellants were denied a fair hearing because Mr. Justice Sharma did not allow them a chance to reply to the State's arguments cannot be considered as it was not pressed before the judge despite being mentioned in the petition for certificate.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion this point cannot be considered because though it was mentioned in the petition for certificate it was apparently not pressed before Mr. Justice Sharma. The next contention of the appellants is that the prior acquittal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellants failed to raise the issue immediately for rectification and did not press it before the judge when seeking certificate.

holdings.text: The prior acquittal in the second case (assault on Puran) does not operate as a bar to conviction in the present case (assault on Tikam) under s. 403 CrPC or res judicata, as the offences are distinct transactions separated by time and place.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention of the appellants is that the prior acquittal in the second case operates as a bar to the conviction in the present case and the High Court ought to have given the appellants the benefit of the prior ac- quittal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offences distinct; ss. 236/237 CrPC apply only to doubtful single acts or series, not here; precedents like Sambasivam and Pritam Singh distinguished as involving same evidence or indivisible confession affecting admissibility.

holdings.text: The Sessions Judge was right in amending the common charge into two separate charges and ordering separate trials for the assaults on Tikam and Puran.

anchor.surface_text: Neither of these provisions is applicable to the present facts because the two offences were distinct and spaced slightly by time and place. The trials were separate as the two incidents were viewed as distinct transactions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assault on Tikam completed before new common object for Puran formed; distinct offences even if connected by time/place.

holdings.text: The earlier judgment in the Puran case is admissible under ss. 40-43 Evidence Act only to show parties and decision, not for appreciating or relying upon the evidence in the present case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence separately recorded and considered; different eyewitnesses; no bar under s.403 CrPC so not relevant for evidence interpretation.

holdings.text: This Court does not review for the third time the evidence accepted by the High Court and Sessions Court absent special circumstances.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Settled practice of the Court; no special circumstances shown.

precedents.citation: Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor Federation of Malaya 1 ... 1950 A.C., 458 at p. 479

anchor.surface_text: Reliance in this connection is placed upon a decision of the Privy Council in a case from Malaya State reported in Sambasivam v. Public Prosecutor Federation of Malaya 1 and particularly the following passage from the judgment of Lord Mac Dermott The effect of a verdict of acquittal pronounced by a companypetent companyrt on a lawful charge and after a lawful trial is number companypletely stated by saying that the person acquitted cannot be tried again for the same offence. 1950 A.C., 458 at p. 479.

precedents.case_name: Sambasivam v Public Prosecutor Federation of Malaya
precedents.cited_proposition: Verdict of acquittal is binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings between the parties; prosecution bound to accept correctness of acquittal and precluded from challenging it
precedents.cited_holding: the person acquitted cannot be tried again for the same offence. To that must be added that the verdict is binding and conclusive in all subsequent proceedings between the parties to the adjudication.

precedents.citation: Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab 1 ... A.I.R. 1956 S.C. 415

anchor.surface_text: The above passage was cited with approval by this Court in Pritam Singh v. State of Punjab 1 . The two cited cases were considered and distinguished by this Court in Mohinder Singh v. State of Punjab 2 and Pritam Singhs case was again distinguished in Gurcharen Singh anr. v. State of Punjab 1 .

precedents.case_name: Pritam Singh v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Evidence leading to acquittal on firearm possession cannot be used in subsequent murder trial

precedents.citation: Mohinder Singh v. State of Punjab 2 ... 1963 3 S.C.R. 585

anchor.surface_text: The two cited cases were considered and distinguished by this Court in Mohinder Singh v. State of Punjab 2 , the case of the Privy Council involved a confession by an accused in which he admitted possession of a firearm and some ammunition which were both offences under the relative law of Malaya State.

precedents.case_name: Mohinder Singh v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Sambasivam and Pritam Singh cases distinguished where acquittal under Arms Act was later than conviction on substantive charge; indivisible confession cannot be split after acquittal on one part

precedents.citation: Gurcharen Singh anr. v. State of Punjab 1 ... Cr. A. No. 140 of 1961, decided on 31-7-63 Unreported

anchor.surface_text: Pritam Singhs case was again distinguished in Gurcharen Singh anr. v. State of Punjab 1 . As pointed out in Mohinder Singh v. State of Punjab 2 , the case of the Privy Council involved a confession by an accused in which he admitted possession of a firearm and some ammunition

precedents.case_name: Gurcharan Singh & Anr v State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Pritam Singh case distinguished where acquittal under Arms Act later than conviction on substantive charge
